definition: to stir up trouble
to provoke/to irritate/to vex/to stir up/to anger/to attract (troubles)/to cause (problems)
is/are/am/yes/to be
variant of 是[shi4]/(used in given names)
abbr. for 非洲[Fei1 zhou1], Africa
to not be/not/wrong/incorrect/non-/un-/in-/to reproach or blame/(colloquial) to insist on/simply must

sentences.english: Green is trying to let sleeping dogs lie.
sentences.chinese: 格林在努力避免招惹是非。

sentences.english: She's prudent and cautious with people; she never provokes a quarrel.
sentences.chinese: 她为人谨慎小心，从不招惹是非。

sentences.english: Jack often gets into fights because he is always looking for trouble.
sentences.chinese: 杰克时常与人打架，因为他老是招惹是非。

sentences.english: Many celebrities like to make waves in order to be kept in the media.
sentences.chinese: 许多名人喜欢招惹是非，来引起媒体的经常关注。

definition: to stir up trouble
variant of 惹是生非[re3 shi4 sheng1 fei1]
to cause trouble
to arouse animosity
to create difficulties/to invite trouble/to be troublesome
to gossip and meddle/to shoot one's mouth off/talkative
to invite disaster
to incite a quarrel (idiom); to sow discord between people/to tell tales/to make mischief
stir up the fire and you get burnt (idiom); to get one's fingers burnt/fig. to suffer on account of one's own meddling
timid/to be afraid of getting involved/to be afraid of getting into trouble
to stir up trouble/to invite disaster
meddling in other people's business
to antagonize people/to make an enemy of sb
disturbance/incident
to meddle/to be a "nosy Parker"/to be too inquisitive about other people's business
to cause sth unfortunate to happen (to oneself or sb else)/to do sth inauspicious/to have a stroke of bad luck
